ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: methods of inquiry, thesis research
I learned sociological methods

I learned the methods used in academic research. I learned which kinds of methods were best for the kinds of data that would best help answer your research question. I learned how to formulate a research question that is unbiased, effective, and takes into account the particularities necessary of your inquiry.
I learned a great deal about sociological research and methods. I feel much more capable to perform research and have a great senior thesis.
I learned a lot about methods

In this course, I learned about the theory and practice of several key methods in social research. Focusing on qualitative methodology, I learned how to devise a research project and how to apply these methods to answer specific research questions. In addition to reading examples of social science research that made use of various methods, I also learned by doing through dedicated class projects.
I learned how I am going to conduct my thesis/senior research project!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Prof Menon was very engaging and helpful, however the course should be more practice oriented rather than lecture
Weaknesses was layout strength was content

Strengths: great prof, the TF was also helpful, the lectures are straightforward, extremely helpful, and easy to understand, each lecture is supplemented with portions where we can engage more in-depth with the material

Weaknesses: I can't think of any but this iteration of the course was obviously impacted by the emergency situations of the professor and teaching fellow. (Not that the class suffered because of it, but just as something to keep in mind)
I think fewer readings would help

I think the course's mixture of instructional texts, research examples, and in-class projects did a good job at making a large amount of material digestible and engaging. Course assignments were well-structured and organized, and class discussions helped tie together the many sources of information used. I do think that the course could benefit from being more streamlined, however, and taking a more formal approach to the methods discussed. In particular,  think that a more unit-based structure that leaned more heavily on instructive texts would help students gain a firmer understanding of the different methods and topics to be covered.

This is probably a hot take but I think there could have been a bit more in-class activities throughout the semester to get everyone engaged with the material. Seemed a bit easy for some students to coast through.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: you gain some foundational frameworks in learning to do social science research
Only if required
Yes. If you need to fulfill your methods requirement for the Sociology major, this is an excellent way to do so.
Yes, if they are looking to do a research project of some sort.
Sure
Yes!
As far as required courses go, this was a good one! It helped me organize my thinking for my thesis, which is a huge relief going into senior year.

Though the course is required for sociology majors, I would recommend SOCY 160 for all students interested in social inquiry. The methods learned, and the logic behind them, is valuable to the study of society from a variety of angles. I think even students with no plans t pursue social research would benefit from the insights gained by the course, because the knowledge that these methods generate (or claim to) is all around us. The course would be especially valuable for students who have primarily had experiences with more quantitative methods.
Absolutely, great class and prepares you for real-world research.
